title: 10,000 Syrian refugees settle in Australia
text:
10,000 Syrian refugees settle in Australia Australian Associated Press March 22, 2017 10:16am 
Australia has welcomed 10,000 Syrian refugees and issued another 2000 visas to people fleeing the war-torn Middle East country. 
Malcolm Turnbull will reportedly confirm the entire 12,000 visas pledged to Syrian refugees in 2015 have been issued during a migrations awards speech at Parliament House in Canberra on Wednesday night. 
His speech is not expected to detail the religious make-up of Syrian refugees processed, but the government has prioritised persecuted Christians over Muslims, the Daily Telegraph reports. 
While Liberal MP Andrew Laming denied the government prioritised refugee intake on the basis of religion, he emphasised the attacks on Christian groups in Syria. 
"You certainly have to ask who the most discriminated groups in Syria as a result of the conflict are, and quite clearly Christian and non-Islamic families are going to be incredibly persecuted," he told reporters. 
"That's utterly self-evident." 
Dr Laming said some Christian groups in Australia had been extremely effective in facilitating the migration process for Christian refugees. 
"In essence, this is a direct application. It's a direct sponsorship," he said. 
Greens senator Nick McKim said regardless of whether the report was true or not, the government should always prioritise on the basis of need. 
"The idea that we would prioritise on religion as opposed to genuine need is quite disgusting. It's racial profiling or religious profiling," he said. 
Shadow attorney-general Mark Dreyfus said Australia had never selected immigrants based on religion and he would be disturbed if the country started to do so. 
More Muslims had been killed in the conflict in the Middle East than members of any other religion, Mr Dreyfus said. 
"This is a sectarian conflict as much as it is anything else," he told reporters in Canberra. 
"Of course, Christians are persecuted in the Middle East and of course Muslims are being persecuted in the Middle East, and members of other religions as well."
